title: Otis Armstrong
text:
Otis D. Armstrong (November 15, 1950 – October 13, 2021) was an American professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He was selected in the first round with the ninth overall pick in the <a href="1973%20NFL%20Draft">1973 NFL Draft</a>. He played for the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a> for his entire career from 1973 to 1980.
High school.
Armstrong attended <a href="Farragut%20Career%20Academy">Farragut High School</a> in Chicago, and was inducted into the <a href="Chicagoland%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Chicagoland Sports Hall of Fame</a>.
College career.
Before his NFL career, Armstrong played for <a href="Purdue%20University">Purdue University</a> becoming the school's all-time leading rusher and leader in all-purpose yards. Armstrong was selected to Purdue's All-Time team in 1987 as part of a celebration of 100 years of football at Purdue. He was inducted into the Purdue Intercollegiate Athletics Hall of Fame in 1997.
Armstrong finished his 3 college seasons with 4,601 All-purpose yards (3,315 rushing yards, 897 yards from kickoff returns and 389 passing yards). He also scored 24 touchdowns (17 rushing and 7 on returns). He was selected the <a href="Big%20Ten">Big Ten</a> MVP in 1972, leading the league in rushing and total offense, while being selected 1st team All-Conference. He participated in 4 All-Star games; the <a href="Hula%20Bowl">Hula Bowl</a>, the <a href="East-West%20Shrine%20Game">East-West Shrine Game</a>, the Coaches' All-American Game, and the Chicago College All-Star game.
Over the course of his Purdue career, Armstrong became the all-time leading rusher in Big Ten Conference and Purdue history and ranked sixth in <a href="NCAA">NCAA</a> history at the time. His total of 3,315 yards in three years bettered the previous mark of 3,212 yards by <a href="Alan%20Ameche">Alan Ameche</a> of Wisconsin - established in four years. He still holds the Purdue single game rushing record (276 yds vs. arch-rival Indiana.) Armstrong finished as the all-time leader in All-Purpose yards at Purdue (4,601 yds), he is currently 4th all-time.
On May 16, 2012; Armstrong was selected for induction into the College Football Hall of Fame. Armstrong will be the 13th Boilermaker (9 players, 4 coaches) inducted into the <a href="College%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">College Football Hall of Fame</a>.
Professional career.
In his second NFL season, Armstrong led the league in rushing yards (1,407) and yards per carry (5.3). In the 1977 season, he assisted the <a href="Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a> to an appearance in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XII">Super Bowl XII</a>, which they lost to the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> 27-10.
Armstrong finished his 8 NFL seasons with 4,453 rushing yards, 123 receptions for 1,302 receiving yards, and 879 yards from kickoff returns. He also scored 32 touchdowns (25 rushing and 7 receiving).
Death.
Otis Armstrong died on October 13, 2021, surrounded by his family and loved ones. He was 70.
